author: By Daniel Politi and Isabella Kwai
title: Offices of Diego Maradona’s Doctor Raided Over His Death
description: The authorities searched the home and offices of the soccer hero’s doctor as part of an investigation into the circumstances of his death last week.
content: BUENOS AIRES — The authorities searched the home and offices of Diego Maradona’s personal doctor on Sunday as part of an investigation into the circumstances surrounding the soccer star’s death last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Gardiner
title: Smart Cruise Control Comes to Motorcycles
description: Cars have had the technology for decades, but bikes from BMW and Ducati will offer the safety systems for the first time, with some adjustments.
content: A self-driving motorcycle wouldn’t make much sense, but the industry is starting to adopt some safety technology from cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Effort to Rescue Endangered Turtles Becomes a Thanksgiving Odyssey
description: After a plane transporting 30 Kemp’s ridley sea turtles to Louisiana from Massachusetts was snagged by delays, frantic calls for help went out.
content: The rescue mission was supposed to be simple: fly 30 endangered turtles to their new home in New Orleans from Cape Cod, Mass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: A Theater’s ‘Last Gasp’ Doesn’t Look Like the End
description: As Split Britches, Peggy Shaw and Lois Weaver have made off-kilter theater for 40 years. Memory loss, and a pandemic, haven’t stopped their creating.
content: Back in March, Peggy Shaw and Lois Weaver, of the theater duo Split Britches, were in Britain, developing a new show, when Covid-19 exploded. It made more sense to stay put than to scamper back home to New York, which looked pretty scary at the time. Weaver, who has spent part of the year in London for nearly two decades, teaching performance at Queen Mary University, had a shared place there, but Shaw’s accommodations across town were an issue.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘We Were Hungry High School Kids in Sheepshead Bay in the Early 1960s’
description: A Chinese takeout place in Brooklyn, watching the nursery and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden Expected to Name Top Economic Officials This Week
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to nominate Neera Tanden, a divisive figure within the Democratic Party, to lead the budget office. He also named an all-female communications staff.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to name top members of his economic team this week, including Cecilia Rouse, a Princeton labor economist, to run the Council of Economic Advisers, and Neera Tanden, the chief executive of the Center for American Progress, to lead the Office of Management and Budget, according to people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: As hiking surges during the coronavirus pandemic, so does the risk of injury.
description: Outdoor activities have become a popular pastime during the coronavirus pandemic as adventure seekers and couch surfers alike take to hiking trails for a bit of a reprieve.
content: Outdoor activities have become a popular pastime during the coronavirus pandemic as adventure seekers and couch surfers alike take to hiking trails for a bit of a reprieve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Jets’ Offense Sputters in Sam Darnold’s Return
description: Miami quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick stepped in to beat one of his many former teams, and the Jets (0-11), in Darnold’s return from a shoulder injury, did not score a touchdown.
content: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick has been through it all during his many stops in the N.F.L. — a backup and a starter, a fill-in and a franchise leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Inskeep
title: Trump Looms Large Now, but Maybe Not Forever
description: One-term presidents generally don’t leave big footprints. And the last four years may be seen as a reaction to the game-changing presidency of Barack Obama.
content: President Trump’s critics warn that history will look unkindly on his effort to overturn a democratic election. This forecast, while understandable, may be wrong. History rarely looks on one-term presidents at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noele Illien
title: Plan to Hold Corporations Liable for Violations Abroad Fails in Switzerland
description: The proposal would have exposed multinational companies to greater scrutiny over human rights and environmental abuses.
content: ZURICH — A proposal in Switzerland to make multinational companies headquartered in the country liable for human rights violations and environmental damage committed by their subsidiaries abroad failed in a referendum on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Barroom Trivia Slayer? Get Your Quiz On Digitally
description: Though many bars are under lockdown restrictions, pub quiz companies still operate online. You provide the booze, they provide the brainteasers.
content: In the spring, just before lockdown hit North Carolina, Steve Bahnaman met some friends at a Cider Brewery, just outside Raleigh, for an evening of bar trivia. His team, Covid Operations (this was back before Covid-19 puns were “super tired,” he explained), won the competition that night. The prize: $40 in bar cash. “Which I’m probably never going to use,” said Mr. Bahnaman, who hasn’t visited a bar or played another game in-person since. “That is very sad.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Afghan Leader Digs In on Peace Talks Despite Progress, Officials Say
description: President Ashraf Ghani is holding up a tentative agreement on the talks’ framework, some officials say. His aides say no agreement was near.
content: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan has refused to let peace talks move forward even though the Taliban and government negotiators have reached a tentative agreement on the talks’ guiding principles, Afghan officials say, further stalling the process despite nearing an apparent breakthrough after months of effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Biden’s doctor says president-elect has hairline fracture after twisting his ankle playing with dog.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. visited an orthopedic specialist in Newark, Del., on Sunday afternoon after he twisted his ankle playing with his one of his dogs over the holiday weekend, according to his office, an injury that his doctor said resulted in hairline fractures that would require him to wear a boot for several weeks.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. visited an orthopedic specialist in Newark, Del., on Sunday afternoon after he twisted his ankle playing with his one of his dogs over the holiday weekend, according to his office, an injury that his doctor said resulted in hairline fractures that would require him to wear a boot for several weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Bah, Pandemic! How Theaters Are Saving ‘A Christmas Carol’
description: Seasonal stagings often underwrite the usual fare. But even without indoor audiences, the tradition lives on — by mail, by screen, by car and by radio.
content: For all his flaws, that cranky old miser Ebenezer Scrooge has been a godsend for American theaters. Through recessions and blizzards and other upheavals, he has drawn small children and big money to his redemption story in “A Christmas Carol.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: ‘Because She’s a Girl’: Lockdown Exposes Gender Gap in U.K. Sports
description: Inequalities are especially pronounced in English youth soccer, where only a handful of clubs have kept training open for future female professionals, while boys at the same level play on.
content: When Lisa Bloor heard that her daughter Abby’s elite-level soccer club was being shut down in England’s latest coronavirus lockdown she faced a tough problem: how to explain that boys at the same level were allowed to keep playing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer
title: ‘I Have Never Seen So Many Toadstools.’ A Bumper Crop of Mushrooms in Ukraine.
description: Hunting for mushrooms deep in the forest is the ideal socially distanced pastime.
content: KHOMUTYNSI, Ukraine — Valery Kravchuk, a seasoned mushroom hunter, pushed aside some dead leaves to reveal his prize: a beautiful blusher, so called because it turns pink when pinched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Recount in two Wisconsin counties reinforces Biden’s victory.
description: The conclusion of the recount adds yet another loss in the Trump campaign’s effort to upend Mr. Biden’s win.
content: Wisconsin’s two largest counties have concluded recounts requested by the Trump campaign, with the results slightly increasing Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s margin of victory and reaffirming his win over President Trump in this month’s election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Shelby Knowles
title: Coronavirus Deaths, Joe Biden, Holiday Windows: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Virus Disruptions Hit 49ers and Broncos, as N.F.L. Crisis Grows
description: The 49ers would need to train away from their headquarters for three weeks under an order from local health officials. The Broncos have none of their quarterbacks available for their game on Sunday.
content: After bobbing and weaving around the coronavirus pandemic for much of the fall, the N.F.L. is facing crises on teams from coast to coast in its final stretch of the regular season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Theaters are fighting to keep ‘A Christmas Carol’ on stage during the pandemic.
description: Through recessions and blizzards and other upheavals, Ebenezer Scrooge has drawn small children and big money to his redemption story in “A Christmas Carol.”
content: Through recessions and blizzards and other upheavals, Ebenezer Scrooge has drawn small children and big money to his redemption story in “A Christmas Carol.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: That Mysterious Monolith in the Utah Desert? It’s Gone, Officials Say
description: The metal structure has been removed, Utah officials said on Saturday, adding that they had not taken it down.
content: As mysteriously as it arrived, a metal monolith that was discovered last week by Utah public safety workers is now gone, officials said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barbara Slavin
title: Why Was Iran’s Top Nuclear Scientist Killed?
description: The assassination of Mohsen Fakhrizadeh isn’t about stopping a bomb — it’s about preventing diplomacy. Joe Biden doesn’t have to let it work.
content: When Israel engineered the assassinations of a half-dozen Iranian nuclear scientists from 2010 to 2012, supporters of these killings argued that they would help slow a nuclear program at a time when multilateral diplomacy was showing little progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 30, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Nike and Coca-Cola Lobby Against Xinjiang Forced Labor Bill
description: Business groups and major companies like Apple have been pressing Congress to alter legislation cracking down on imports of goods made with forced labor from persecuted Muslim minorities in China.
content: WASHINGTON — Nike and Coca-Cola are among the major companies and business groups lobbying Congress to weaken a bill that would ban imported goods made with forced labor in China’s Xinjiang region, according to congressional staff members and other people familiar with the matter, as well as lobbying records that show vast spending on the legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Alexander Burns
title: One Seat, Competing Pressures as Newsom Considers Senate Pick
description: Alex Padilla, California’s secretary of state, has emerged as the front-runner to succeed Kamala Harris. But Gov. Gavin Newsom appears to be in no rush to make his choice.
content: SACRAMENTO — Since Gavin Newsom’s days as a young upstart running for mayor of San Francisco through more than two decades of public life, Alex Padilla has been a stalwart ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: A Season of Footnotes Limps to Its Conclusion
description: The wheezing college football show goes on without some star players and highly paid coaches and with, in one case, a female kicker.
content: Sarah Fuller has been in far more demanding circumstances than she was on Saturday. Just last week she was in goal for the Vanderbilt women’s soccer team during its victory in the Southeastern Conference tournament championship game. But when Fuller took the field with the Vanderbilt football team on Saturday and chipped the second-half kickoff about 30 yards downfield against Missouri, she became the first woman to play in one of college football’s top conferences.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Drugs, Guns and Cash: This Is ‘Cartel TikTok’
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 29, 2020.
content: “The message has to be quick, it has to be engaging, and it has to be viral. Violence becomes fun, or even put to music.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Umansky
title: Turn Articles Into Poetry
description: A cento is a poem written using borrowed lines, like ones from this publication. Don’t forget to give credit.
content: Imitation is the best kind of flattery. All creative people, whether they be writers, artists, dancers, singers or actors, know that. Think about the performers on a TV show like “The Voice,” who sometimes perform the song of a judge they are targeting. Sometimes, it is imitation that gets them on the team of their dreams. It is the same with poetry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 29, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 29, 2020.
content: An article last Sunday about dividend payouts misstated the amount that American corporations have sold in bonds this year. Through Nov. 10, they sold $1.6 trillion, not billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Party With Nearly 400 People Is Shut Down in Manhattan
description: The sheriff’s office has responded to similar events every weekend for the last several months, even as the pandemic worsens.
content: Sheriff’s deputies arrived at a building in Midtown Manhattan just before 3 a.m. on Saturday and found almost 400 people drinking and partying inside. Few were wearing face masks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Amanda Seyfried Finally Stakes Her Claim
description: The “Mean Girls” and “Mamma Mia!” actress knows her performance as Marion Davies in“Mank” will be a turning point in her career. But first, she had to put some distance between herself and Hollywood.
content: The goats didn’t want to go out in the morning, Amanda Seyfried said. There was one in particular that was giving her trouble, the one Seyfried described as the “God-knows-how-big-she-is goat.” This one was spoiling for a fight. This one could not be moved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Levin
title: Shut Down Your Computers, Kids, and Lace Up
description: Teens and tweens need exercise, period. Many parents are finding informal, creative and encouraging ways to get their isolated offspring outside safely.
content: As any parent overseeing homeschool knows: Zoom P.E. is hardly a hard-driving Peloton class. It’s more like your kid lying on the floor of the living room doing halfhearted leg-lifts by the light of her laptop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Wall Street Is Thankful
description: Markets hit all-time highs this week, breaking pre-pandemic records and reflecting confidence in Biden’s administration.
content: Greetings from the land of leftovers. Cut yourself a slice of cold pie and catch up on the business news you need to know for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

title: Saweetie, City Girls and the Female Rapper Renaissance
description: Streaming, social media and the tireless work of trailblazers have helped change the hip-hop landscape.
content: In the 1980s and 1990s, it often felt like hip-hop would only allow one female rapper to thrive at a time, maybe two. The genre was rife with systemic sexism, and limited resources all around made it even more challenging for women to break through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas St. Fleur
title: Watch a Lunar Eclipse, or at Least Try To
description: Penumbral eclipses are subtle, but there are good reasons to try to notice one.
content: This evening as you sneak some late-night Thanksgiving leftovers, take a moment to marvel at the full moon. Do you notice anything different? It’s subtle, but on early Monday (Sunday night if you’re on the west coast), the full moon should appear a bit darker than usual. That’s because you’re witnessing a penumbral lunar eclipse, a celestial occurrence in which the moon dips behind Earth’s faint, outer shadow, or penumbra.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: The Beat at the Heart of ‘Lovers Rock’
description: Steve McQueen’s new “Small Axe” anthology includes a film that centers on an offshoot of reggae that represented big shifts in the music, and in Black British culture.
content: The lovesick kiss-off “Silly Games” and its indelible high note play a pivotal part in “Lovers Rock,” one of five pieces in the director Steve McQueen’s new “Small Axe” anthology, which examines Black British life across the ’60s, ’70s and ’80s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Fabio Bucciarelli
title: The Lost Days That Made Bergamo a Coronavirus Tragedy
description: The northern Italian province became one of the deadliest killing fields for the virus in the Western world. But a Times investigation found that faulty guidance and bureaucratic delays rendered the toll far worse than it had to be.
content: BERGAMO, Italy — When Franco Orlandi, a usually hale former truck driver, arrived in mid-February with a cough and fever at an emergency room in the northern Italian province of Bergamo, doctors determined that he had a flu and sent him home. Two days later, an ambulance brought the 83-year-old back. He couldn’t breathe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Once again, a cat is set to join the ranks of presidential pets.
description: When he was running for president, Joseph R. Biden Jr. said it was time for a pet to be put back in the White House.
content: When he was running for president, Joseph R. Biden Jr. said it was time for a pet to be put back in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Unable to meet in person, some A.A. members ‘thank Zoom for their very survival.’
description: Their meetings used to take place discreetly in the basements of churches, a spare room at the Y.M.C.A., the back of a cafe. But when the pandemic hit last spring, members of Alcoholics Anonymous and other groups of recovering substance abusers found those doors quickly shut.
content: Their meetings used to take place discreetly in the basements of churches, a spare room at the Y.M.C.A., the back of a cafe. But when the pandemic hit last spring, members of Alcoholics Anonymous and other groups of recovering substance abusers found those doors quickly shut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Keep the good eating going with a caramelized onion galette to pair with leftover turkey, a simple spaghetti al limone, or a baked risotto with greens.
content: Good morning. The eggnog’s flowing where I stay, garlands rising, Christmas music playing, all the markers of holiday cheer. It’s a little out of character. But we’re building a bulwark against the strangeness of 2020, maybe? We’re anyway re-nesting in a nest that’s been largely the same since March. It’s been nice. And with Thanksgiving behind us, we’re baking like mad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina and Hank Stephenson
title: Democrats made inroads in Arizona. But it’s a deeply divided place.
description: PHOENIX — In the moonlight, dozens of people hollered and embraced, dropping the rules of social distancing as they celebrated a win after a long year: hundreds of thousands of Latino voters registered, calls made and doors knocked amid a pandemic that had devastated their communities. Though it would be days before the final result in Arizona was clear, the people working to shore up Latino support for Democrats in the state were already convinced that they helped shape history. They had come through the crucible of a pervasive anti-immigrant sentiment and a decade later, flipped the state and delivered wins.
content: PHOENIX — In the moonlight, dozens of people hollered and embraced, dropping the rules of social distancing as they celebrated a win after a long year: hundreds of thousands of Latino voters registered, calls made and doors knocked amid a pandemic that had devastated their communities. Though it would be days before the final result in Arizona was clear, the people working to shore up Latino support for Democrats in the state were already convinced that they helped shape history. They had come through the crucible of a pervasive anti-immigrant sentiment and a decade later, flipped the state and delivered wins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Jennifer Psaki to Be Press Secretary as Biden Names All-Female Communications Team
description: Ms. Psaki, who served in prominent communications roles in the Obama administration, said she saw her job as trying to “rebuild trust.”
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Sunday announced an all-female White House communications staff, with Jennifer Psaki, a veteran of the Obama administration, in the most visible role as White House press secretary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: The ‘R’ of R.B.G.
description: Emma Craven-Matthews makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Before we begin, please rise for the 71A national anthem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Should Isolation Periods Be Shorter for People With Covid-19?
description: Patients are usually most infectious two days before symptoms begin and for five days after, a new analysis finds.
content: People with Covid-19, the illness caused by the coronavirus, are most infectious about two days before symptoms begin and for five days afterward, according to a new analysis of previous research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Adriana Zehbrauskas
title: Despite Biden’s vow to halt construction of the border wall, the Trump administration is expanding it.
description: DOUGLAS, Ariz. — Four years ago, President Trump took office with a pledge to build a towering wall on America’s border with Mexico — a symbol of his determination to halt immigration from countries to the south and build a barrier that would long outlast him.
content: DOUGLAS, Ariz. — Four years ago, President Trump took office with a pledge to build a towering wall on America’s border with Mexico — a symbol of his determination to halt immigration from countries to the south and build a barrier that would long outlast him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets and Julia Carmel
title: Black Voguers Populate Billboards in a Times Square ‘Midnight Moment’
description: The opportunity to stage “Black Magic” in Times Square “was a great proposition to do something transgressive,” said the artist Rashaad Newsome.
content: Just before midnight every evening in December, some 70 digital billboards encircling the gaudy canyon of Times Square will be co-opted for three minutes by slow-motion images of Black voguers, performing dances of resistance, resilience and liberation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Diego Maradona’s Long Shadow
description: From Ariel Ortega to Lionel Messi, dozens of players have been hailed as the next Maradona, the heir to his famed No. 10. But the fit was never perfect.
content: It was nothing more, really, than a ruffle of the hair and a kiss on the cheek. There was no pomp or circumstance that day in 1994, no words of wisdom whispered in the ear or sweeping gesture made for the crowd. Diego Maradona left the field, and Ariel Ortega replaced him on it. But that was all it took. The torch, it was decided, had been passed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: Leadership of U.N. Human Rights Body Becomes Proxy Battle for World Powers
description: A fight over the council’s presidency is seen by some as an effort by China, Russia and Saudi Arabia to put a more compliant state in control ahead of greater involvement by the Biden administration.
content: GENEVA — The annual choice of who will steer the United Nations’ top human rights organization is usually done quietly and by consensus. For months, this year’s selection seemed to follow that script.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Giants Seize Share of N.F.C. East Lead but Lose Daniel Jones
description: The quarterback injured his hamstring in the third quarter and did not return as the Giants stretched their winning streak to three games.
content: CINCINNATI — After the Giants lost their starting quarterback, they held off a late rally by the Joe Burrow-less Cincinnati Bengals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Coverage That’s Fit for a Queen
description: Our pop culture editor in London talks about the popularity of “The Crown” on both sides of the Atlantic, and giving the people what they want.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: A Cat Is Said to Be Joining the Bidens in the White House
description: The last cat to live in the White House, India, belonged to President George W. Bush.
content: When he was running for president, Joseph R. Biden Jr. said it was time for a pet to be put back in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano and Emma Grillo
title: Learn a New Cookie Recipe or Make Invisible Ink
description: This week, listen to the music of Billie Holiday, attend a fashion workshop or get your tarot cards read.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Dear Joe, It’s Not About Iran’s Nukes Anymore
description: Biden wants to reinstate the nuclear deal, but first he must confront the new Middle East.
content: With the assassination by Israel of Iran’s top nuclear warhead designer, the Middle East is promising to complicate Joe Biden’s job from day one. President-elect Biden knows the region well, but if I had one piece of advice for him, it would be this: This is not the Middle East you left four years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: New York City Will Reopen Elementary Schools and Reduce Hybrid Learning
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced an abrupt shift in managing schools during the pandemic. Officials had faced criticism that they prioritized activities like indoor dining over children’s well-being.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Sunday that he would reopen public elementary schools, abruptly shifting policy in the face of widespread criticism that officials were placing more of a priority on economic activities like indoor dining than the well-being of New York City’s children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tess DeMeyer and Ilana Panich-Linsman
title: The College Athletes Who Are Allowed to Make Big Bucks: Cheerleaders
description: Because cheerleading is not governed by the N.C.A.A., its participants can sign lucrative endorsement deals that would lead to punishment for most college athletes, including soon-to-be N.F.L. and N.B.A. millionaires.
content: During the three years Jamie Andries spent as a member of the University of Oklahoma cheerleading team, she cheered at two Big 12 championship football games, the Orange Bowl, the Sugar Bowl, the Rose Bowl and the 2016 Final Four.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Sokol
title: With Art Basel canceled, Miami looks inward — and the show goes on.
description: Art Basel Miami Beach, the annual fair that usually draws the contemporary art world to South Florida and was scheduled for this week, has been canceled — a cultural casualty of the coronavirus.
content: Art Basel Miami Beach, the annual fair that usually draws the contemporary art world to South Florida and was scheduled for this week, has been canceled — a cultural casualty of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Republicans and Democrats Need to Work Together. Earmarks Can Help.
description: Nothing greases the gears of government quite like pork.
content: As the Trump presidency fades to black, it is time for Washington to get to work. In embracing Joe Biden, the American people cast a vote for civility, pragmatism and competence. Lawmakers now have a duty to hunker down and find ways to make progress on critical issues. But with both chambers of Congress narrowly divided and ideologically polarized, coming together on even the most modest deals could prove daunting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Dave Prowse, Man Behind Darth Vader’s Mask, Is Dead at 85
description: Mr. Prowse went from being a weight lifting champion in Britain to helping portray one of the most memorable villains in movie history. But his voice did not make the edit.
content: Dave Prowse, the British actor who gave the imposing physical presence — but not the voice — to Darth Vader in the original “Star Wars” trilogy, died on Saturday in a hospital in London. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: In statehouse races, suburban voters’ disgust with Trump didn’t translate into a rebuke of other Republicans.
description: WEXFORD, Pa. — Just a few seats shy of a majority in the State House of Representatives, Democrats in Pennsylvania this year zeroed in on Republican-held suburban districts, where disdain for President Trump ran hot.
content: WEXFORD, Pa. — Just a few seats shy of a majority in the State House of Representatives, Democrats in Pennsylvania this year zeroed in on Republican-held suburban districts, where disdain for President Trump ran hot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: East Asia adjusts its response to the latest coronavirus outbreak.
content: Compared with the U.S. and Europe, much of East Asia still has the coronavirus relatively in check. But as cases have soared back to alarming levels in recent weeks, South Korea, Japan and Hong Kong have had to quickly recalibrate their strategies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton and Vanessa Friedman
title: The Luxury E-Commerce Wars Heat Up
description: On one side: Amazon. On the other: a new alliance of brands and platforms. Who will win?
content: In 2015, the chairman and controlling shareholder of the luxury goods group Richemont, Johann Rupert, took to the stage at an industry conference in Monte Carlo and issued a rallying cry to some of his biggest rivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gerald Narciso
title: For One Day, the N.H.L. Arena Moved to the Mountains
description: Several N.H.L. players and an Olympic gold medal-winning figure skater boarded helicopters bound for mountains outside Vancouver, British Columbia, to play pickup hockey in a picturesque setting.
content: Several N.H.L. players and an Olympic gold medal-winning figure skater boarded helicopters bound for mountains outside Vancouver, British Columbia, to play pickup hockey in a picturesque setting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: Listen to Indigenous People
description: Expand your understanding of Native history issues beyond the fourth Thursday of November. Here are some Indigenous podcasters recommending their favorite Native-made audio.
content: The Indigenous people of the land now called North America are often only brought up in the past tense in primary school classrooms. The fact is they are a growing population, an increasing demographic in the country and in Congress, yet most Americans are woefully uninformed about their histories and present-day struggles. Podcasts can help fill in the gaps, and there are plenty of shows made by Indigenous people. Don’t know where to start? Native podcast-makers recommend their favorites.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Chris Dodd: ‘The Lessons of Nuremberg Must Be Continually Relearned’
description: Former Senator Christopher J. Dodd writes of his father’s role at the World War II military tribunal, and the lessons that can be drawn today.

title: How Joe Biden Can Unify the Country
description: Many readers view the political divide as the greatest challenge facing the president-elect.
content: We had asked readers what they thought was the greatest challenge facing the president-elect and what advice they would give him. We published several responses on Saturday. Below are a few more, reflecting the most common answer: the need to heal a divided country.
source.name: The New York Times
